description:
Mammarenavirus juninense is a species of virus belonging to the genus Mammarenavirus, which is part of the Arenaviridae family. This virus is primarily found in South America and is the causative agent of Argentine hemorrhagic fever, a severe and potentially fatal viral illness.

Mammarenavirus juninense is a single-stranded, ambisense RNA virus, with a genome composed of two RNA segments. The virus is primarily transmitted to humans through contact with rodents, particularly the drylands vesper mouse (Calomys musculinus), which serves as the natural reservoir host.

The virus infects human cells, primarily targeting the immune system, and can lead to a range of symptoms, including fever, headache, muscle pain, gastrointestinal issues, and in severe cases, hemorrhaging and organ failure. Early diagnosis and appropriate medical care are crucial for managing the disease and reducing the risk of complications.

Ongoing research and surveillance efforts are essential to better understand the epidemiology, transmission dynamics, and potential public health implications of this significant viral pathogen.
